ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Jeff
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeffrey Stoike.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeffrey Stoike
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was great. Alex and Shane also helped a bunch as well!
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  What?
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff Stoike
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff

Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was a great resource and always offering to help with his areas of expertise. His relaxed attitude was also very calming during these stressful times. Marlyse was also an amazing help on plant ID. It's good to know we are surrounded by so many people that are the best at what they do.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is the most important class a Master of Forestry student can take at FES. The material and hands-on nature of the course is critical to learning and bringing together concepts taught elsewhere in the MF curriculum.
best class at FES. also the most monstrous--soo much work and for the most part the pedagogical approach is to just go over the basics and let students figure out the rest.
This is the most practical class I've taken at FES.

While the lectures are valuable, most of the learning is done outside of class. The process of constructing the plan is a valuable experience and I think that I learned more and applied my learning more in this class than in any other class I have taken at FES. Professor Ashton and the TAs were exceptionally helpful.

The only less-than-excellent areas, question 4 (pace), and question 10 (clarity of explanation), are not really because of the teaching. Mark's teaching is excellent and is the best we can imagine for the circumstances. However the circumstances are the problem. The semester is too short for the amount of information, synthesis, and application of the information that needs to take place. Work continues into the spring semester, and is sometimes not finished until June.The solution is not obvious, but it's out there somewhere. Making this a 2-semester class, or introducing elements of it in earlier classes like silviculture (squeeze), may be beneficial. The intensity of the pace affected the quality of the work, especially with other classes being neglected. By necessity of course, we were still learning much needed skills during lectures near the end of the semester that we wished we had learned in the beginning, though of course there was just not enough time. We would have liked to hit the ground running, but never had a moment to see the powerpoint on walking, and ended up crawling at lightning speed across the finish line. In nappies.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Class project is the focus of this course and a very good experience.

The field experience, the fact that you end the semester with a much more thorough and nuanced understanding of the forest than when you started. This is not a cram-and-forget type of course, but rather a course that stays with you for years afterward.
The best aspects of this course were working with my partner, bouncing ideas around with other classmates, and interacting with the landowner my partner and I worked with
If I write "frolicking the forest on sunny autumn mornings" will that negate my anonymity?
the final product we created is real and substantial and important to people in the real world!
While you don't always feel prepared to take on the tasks in this course, you are forced to and in doing so become more confident and learn a lot. I really like the field trips.
I can now claim to have acquired actual skills.
Working with a team for a client. Having the opportunity to work through the process of constructing a management plan.

Applicative learning. This class sums up everything I hoped to learn at FES. It came at a great time also - after enough time to learn some skills to apply, but with enough time left to fill in the holes of which I am now aware.
Field trips.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Biometrics lecture (and how to analyze data through calculations) should be provided by someone other than Dr. Ashton -- this is not his strength in explaining clearly.
Dr. Ashton is much better in the field than he is in the classroom. The classroom lectures could be tightened up, and the concepts could be more coherently explained.
The lecture time could have been more structured to discuss key subjects. For example, the lecture on basal area would have been more helpful if we had worked through some examples.
we needed more time--maybe we could have at least been assigned to properties and visited our sites once in the spring semester prior.

Some of the lectures are too theoretical and aren't as helpful as they could be at explaining how students should tackle certain aspects of the management plan. In particular the sampling lecture and the data analysis lecture should be more focused on technical skills rather than the theory behind this concepts. I think this would be much more helpful for students and it would avoid a lot of confusion on the part of groups. It seems that every group had to figure out the data analysis portion on their own rather than having a clear set of instructions that we all followed.
This is a course where you can never have too much time.

I think that there is a need to add lectures pertaining to management alternatives for non-forested ecosystems. Or bring in a lecturer who can speak to ecological engineering, green infrastructure and landscape management more broadly.Another possible area of interest to students might be additional lectures on data representation/communication. How can we use the information from our bar graphs and pie charts and present them in a way that a lay-person, rather than just a forester, can understand. Some tips and techniques or references on this front would be helpful.These may just be added bonuses, as the class covers many topics broadly and (appropriately) leaves it up to the student to make the most important decisions.

As stated above, pace and clarity. We are getting a great overall experienceof what we have to go through to put together a plan. However, if the data is what is most important, it is not necessarily going to be that accurate because of the season and the limited time. We are learning as we go, and so the quality of the data changes over the course of the semester. Also, because of what we learn, our values and goals change over the course of the semester, and this also affects the gathering of the data.Overall still, it is a great experience. I say "is" because we're still working on it! This issue may also need attention.
Some of the lectures could be shortened or cleaned up a bit. This was particularly true for the social assessment lecture.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Field experience was a core component of the course and really rewarding.
N/A
N/A

As stated above, the tricky part was that we did not learn certain skills until the end of the semester, after which it was too late to apply in the field. Obviously we cannot just have all the lectures the first week, so this is a problem without an obvious solution. One suggestion could be going into less detail -- giving a slightly-more-than-a-summary lecture on everything we will need to know in the first couple weeks, then going further in depth later in the semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Jeff was great but wasn't able to answer a lot of technical questions, but whenever I asked him something he didn't know he was helpful and responsive in finding someone who could answer it for me.
The TA was available. We could have taken more advantage as a group to have the TA or instructor visit our site earlier in the semester.

Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff Stoike provided helpful information for the social assessment content of the course. It would have been helpful to have a teaching assistant available for questions about forestry measurements and data analysis, as well.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Available, friendly, and knowledgeable about social issues.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Available and friendly. Planning went well. Big shout out to Alex and Shane for technical back-up.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was very accessible and responsive.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff was very strong all around, knowledge-wise and support-wise. The only space was plant identification, but we have plenty of plant identifiers around.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is the capstone to the MF degree and a critical course for all MFs to take.
I consider this course the capstone of my time at FES.
This course was a wonderful capstone to the MF curriculum. I really enjoyed the opportunity to apply what I have learned in other classes, such as Stand Dynamics, Silviculture, Soils, etc.
It was a great course to round out/ fill in my time atFES--one of the best/ if not the best course I have taken here. It brought so many concepts and skills together.
I'm an MF.

To me, this class was about systems thinking. Now that I've gathered all of the information, it is up to me (and my group) to represent the information in a way that communicates all of the connections. This class has helped to bring together all of the fragments of knowledge and information that I have collected both during my time at FES and prior to studying here. It is certainly the most useful class I have taken to date.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Capstone for degree -- heard it was the best course for MFs to take (which is true).
Everyone knows that this class is THE class to take after Silviculture.
Took as capstone class. Seemed like good way to synthesize my coursework thus far.
i much prefer clinical courses and this is the best one on land mangement

Because I thought it would round out my education by allowing me to "practice" many of the concepts I have learned in other classes. It really pushes you to think and learn on your feet. Also I think Mark Ashton is by far the best instructor I have had at FES and therefore I seek out courses he teaches.
I need(ed) to improve my field skills.
See above comments. I knew that I wanted to take this course when I applied to school at FES.
I took this course to learn to apply everything in my toolbox. The toolbox was used up, refilled, dropped a few times, and is now overflowing.
It is pretty much the capstone course for MFs.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely.
It actually exceeded my expectations, which is saying a lot, since I came in with high expectations.
Mark's classes are the few that I feel that I learn something concrete and practical from. Always a steep learning curve though.
yes
Yes, although I would have like to do a little more data analysis but I didn't have time to do all components of the project so I handed that over to other team members.
Yes.
Yes, most definitely.
Exceeded.
Yes, very much so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Critical experience learning to work with a partner on a very intense and work-heavy project.
I couldn't have done all the work without being part of a group.
It was great. My partner and I worked hard to balance our workload and support one another with our particular skills.
It was sometimes difficult to keep a holistic view of the property when team divied up responsibilities.
wow. this whole class is one huge group project.

This class would not be possible without a team. There were great and not so great things about my group. I think that picking your own group is the most helpful. I don't know other ways to say how to make this component better because there are just going to be some people who don't do anything and get away with it. I think that perhaps a check in with Mark half way through the semester would be helpful, as well as an evaluation of all the team members at the end. I think maybe each person should have to write what they completed for the course. I would also like to know what my team mates think my strengths and weaknesses are and if there was some way to communicate this I would appreciate the feedback from my classmates.

This is an extremely high-pressure environment, and it was tough to have a partner who was less invested in the project than I was. On the other hand, it would have been impossible to do alone. I think that 3 people is probably an optimal group size, unless both partners are truly equally engaged.

Sharing the responsibility, reflecting and processing as a group, collectively coming up with solutions to sometimes baffling problems, complementing each others skill sets...these are all advantages and occasionally disadvantages to group work. I have no complaints, only complements.

Everyone has different working styles, and this caused noticeable disagreements in almost every group. Some were predictable, others were sadly just differences in working style or expectations. This was a good lesson in managing group dynamics, as well as keeping work in perspective. There is always more to be done to make the product better, so this class draws you in, and sometimes it is unhealthy. This is fine for some, not for others. Other aspects of life suffer because of this.
Difficult to manage a group, but important for splitting up the scope of work.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Absolutely take the course if you want field experience and "soup to nuts" understanding of forestland management.
This has to be your top priority or you will be unhappy for having taken it.
Make sure that you ask questions when you are confused and really try to complete things when they are due so that you dont get too far behind by the end of the semester.
work hard. stick to the deadlines. have clear work plan and open communication with team. learn tree id early.
Find a team with people who have a complementary skill set and be prepared to put in a lot of time.
Work with someone who really cares. Be prepared to give up all your weekends. Have fun -- it's a unique opportunity.
Be prepared to sacrifice most of the other things in your life to work on your project, but also be prepared to enjoy it.

Sit in on this class the year before. This is tricky because it's the first semester, so most people do not know whether they are going to take it. If you are an MF, just sit in on it anyway. Details will be over your head but it will help with the overall picture of what you are going to have to synthesize.
Meet the deadlines Mark sets -it's easy not to do but crucial.
